properties.summary:
• Europe – Germany
    Anti-war protests in Cologne escalated into clashes with federal police over military policy reforms.
  • Middle East – Israel
    Nationwide demonstrations called for an immediate ceasefire and the release of hostages in Gaza.
properties.title: Political risks intelligence bulletin – 1 September 2025
properties.body:
Political Risk Intelligence Bulletins provide concise summaries of the most significant incidents or developments reported in the last 48–72 hours. For more detailed information on all events, please visit the Events page.

AMERICAS

Guyana – 31 August: In Georgetown city, in a joint statement, the Guyana Defence Force (GDF) and Guyana Police Force (GPF) denounced an alleged gunfire attack by Venezuela targeting a Guyanese boat carrying electoral material, ahead of Guyanaʼs general elections on 1 September. The boat contained a patrol of officers from the GDF and GPF, which was escorting nine election officials distributing ballots to polling stations in remote areas of the region. The attack took place near the town of Bamboo on the Cuyuní river. No injuries to the electoral staff or damage to the ballots were reported. This is the first election since escalating tensions between the two countries over a territorial dispute over Essequibo region.

United States – 29 August: In Washington city, US Secretary of State Marco Rubio denied and revoked visas of members of the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) and Palestinian Authority (PA), before the upcoming United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) scheduled for September. US President Donald Trumpʼs administration said the PLO and PA members must commit to repudiating the events of 7 October 2023, and “end incitement to terrorism in education”. Trump administration also urged the members to not utilise international lawfare campaigns, including appeals to the International Criminal Court (ICC) and International Court of Justice (ICJ), and to halt efforts to guarantee the recognition of the Palestinian state.

ASIA-PACIFIC

Australia – 31 August: In the cities of Adelaide and Melbourne, protesters clashed during a pro-Palestine rally and a March for Australia anti-immigration rally respectively. Demonstrations related to March for Australia were also held in Perth, Sydney, and Townsville cities. Counter-protests by groups, including Refugee Action Coalition (RAC) and Palestinian Action Group, were also reported in these cities.

China – 31 August: In Tianjin city, China’s President Xi Jinping hosted India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modi for a bilateral meeting during his visit to China for the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit from 31 August to 1 September. Both leaders reaffirmed that India and China are partners, not rivals, and emphasised that differences between the two countries should not become disputes. They highlighted the need for co-operation for a multipolar Asia and world. Modi stressed the importance of peace along the border, and both leaders expressed commitment to ‘a fair, reasonable, and mutually acceptable resolution of the boundary question’. They also agreed to expand common ground on counter-terrorism and fair trade in multilateral forums.


Thailand – 29 August: In Bangkok city, the Constitutional Court dismissed suspended Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra from office effective from 1 July over charges of ethical violations by prioritising personal relations with Cambodia’s Senate President Hun Sen over Thailandʼs national interests during a phone call in June. The ruling followed a petition by 36 members of the senate seeking the removal of Shinawatra from office. The verdict also led to the dismissal of the entire cabinet effective from 1 July.

MIDDLE EAST AND NORTH AFRICA

Israel – 30 August: In Tel Aviv city, thousands of civilians joined nationwide protests calling on the government to urgently agree to a ceasefire deal to secure the release of hostages held in Gaza. The protests came after the recovery of two hostages’ bodies. The proposed deal, already accepted by Hamas militants, includes a 60-day truce during which 10 hostages and the bodies of 18 captives would be released, with negotiations continuing for the release of remaining hostages and a permanent end to the war.

SUB-SAHARAN AFRICA

Benin – 31 August: The ruling majority, comprising political parties Republican Bloc (Bloc Républicain: BR) and Progressive Union for Renewal (Union progressiste pour le renouveau: UPR), nominated Minister of Economy and Finance Romuald Wadagni as the presidential candidate for the elections in 2026. Wadagni was appointed as the minister of economy and finance in 2016.

Sudan – 30 August: In Nyala city, the Sudan Founding Alliance (TASIS) led by paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) swore in Commander of the RSF General Mohamed Hamdan Daglo as the chairman of the presidential council. TASIS is an administration parallel to the Transitional Sovereignty Council (TSC) led by General Abdel Fattah Al-Burhan.

WESTERN AND CENTRAL EUROPE

Germany – 30 August: On Mechthildisstraße in Cologne city, anti-war protesters of the Disarm Rheinmetall (Rheinmetall entwaffnen) group clashed with the Federal Police (Bundespolizei: BPOL). Police arrested an unspecified number of protesters who allegedly attacked and injured 12 police officers. Police used tear gas and batons to disperse the crowd. Another allied group of at least 3,000 protesters gathered at Heumarkt square and raised slogans against a proposed military service law. They also called for demilitarisation of Germany, and urged for better relations between Germany and Russia.

United Kingdom – 29 August: In Epping town, the Court of Appeal granted the UK government permission to keep asylum seekers in the Bell hotel. The court ruled that the closure of the hotel would result in obvious consequences on the government’s duty to house asylum seekers. A High Court previously ruled that asylum seekers must be moved out of the hotel by 12 September due to an increase in anti-immigration protests after a migrant of Ethiopian origin was charged with sexual assault.

properties.summary:
• Asia-Pacific – China & India
    Leaders reaffirmed diplomatic cooperation and border stability during the SCO summit in Tianjin.
  • Asia-Pacific – Thailand
    Thailand’s Constitutional Court dismissed the prime minister and cabinet over ethical violations.

properties.summary:
• Sub-Saharan Africa – Sudan
    The RSF-led Sudan Founding Alliance established a parallel presidential council in Nyala.
  • Americas – United States
    The US revoked visas of PLO and Palestinian Authority officials ahead of the UN General Assembly.
